title: Tokelauan people
text:
Tokelauan people are the <a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20of%20Oceania">indigenous</a> <a href="Polynesians">Polynesian people</a> of <a href="Tokelau">Tokelau</a>, an island group in <a href="Polynesia">Polynesia</a>, in the Pacific Ocean. The native language of the Tokelauans is <a href="Tokelauan%20language">Tokelauan</a>. 
The group's home islands are a <a href="dependent%20territory">dependent territory</a> of <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>. 77% of Tokelau's population of 1,650 claims Tokelauan ancestry, while 8,676 Tokelauans live in New Zealand. A small number also live in <a href="Samoa">Samoa</a>.
Language.
The <a href="Tokelauan%20language">Tokelauan language</a> is part of the <a href="Polynesian%20languages">Polynesian language family</a>. Most Tokelauans are fluent in both <a href="English%20language">English</a> and Tokelauan. There are approximately 4,000 speakers, the majority of whom live in New Zealand.
Diaspora.
The majority of Tokelauans live in New Zealand, concentrated in the large <a href="Wellington">Wellington</a> suburbs of the <a href="Hutt%20Valley">Hutt Valley</a> and <a href="Porirua">Porirua</a>, as well as <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a>. They are the sixth largest <a href="Pacific%20Islander">Pacific Islander</a> ethnic group in New Zealand, and one of the most socio-economically deprived. Migration to New Zealand began in the 1950s and increased in the 1960s under a government resettlement scheme driven by fears of overpopulation and a tropical cyclone striking the islands. The New Zealand-based population exceeded that of Tokelau in 1976, and immigration declined after that point.
Culture.
Religion.
As of 2019, 50.4% of people belong to <a href="Congregational%20Christian%20Churches">Congregational Christian Church</a> while 38.7% belong to <a href="Catholic%20church">Catholic church</a>. The rest of the population adhere to various Christian denomination such as <a href="Presbyterianism">Presbyterian</a>. Roman Catholic is mostly practiced in Nukunonu whereas inhabitants of the islands of <a href="Atafu">Atafu</a> and <a href="Fakaofo">Fakaofo</a> adhere to the Congregationalism. Prior to the arrival of Christianity, Tokelauans worshiped a god named <a href="Tui%20Tokelau">Tui Tokelau</a>.
Sports.
<a href="Netball">Netball</a>, <a href="Rugby%20football">rugby</a>, <a href="association%20football">football</a> and <a href="cricket">cricket</a> are popular in Tokelau. Tokelau Games are held yearly.
